description: Catalog of WildFly 37.0.0.Beta1-SNAPSHOT features (incomplete for now) to provision a WildFly server

legend.layer: The Galleon layer name to use to provision the feature.
legend.description: The textual description of the layer.
legend.stability: One of default, community, preview and experimental. community and default stability features are available by default.
legend.note: To highlight a particularity that occurs when provisioning this layer.
legend.glowDiscoverable: WildFly Glow (CLI or support in the WildFly Maven Plugin), can discover the layer from the API used in your deployment. If false, it must be added using the WildFly Glow addOn name.
legend.glowAddOn: The name of the WildFly Glow addOn to use to provision this functionality when using Wildfly Glow.
legend.glowRules: The list of rules that WildFly Glow uses to discover that your deployment requires this layer (API in use, expected XML descriptor, ...).
legend.feature-pack: The Galleon feature-pack that defines the layer.
legend.managementModel: The part of the management model this layer brings to the server configuration. Can be empty if this layer only aggregates some layers.
legend.dependencies: The list of layers this layer depends on. Those layers are also provisioned when this layer is provisioned.
legend.configuration: Environment variables and system properties that can be used to configure the layer.
legend.modelReference: The model reference of the resources that this feature-pack can provision
legend.mavenCoordinates: The Maven GroupId, ArtifactId and Version of the feature-pack
legend.featurePackLocation: The XML content to configure the WildFly Maven Plugin to use this feature-pack
legend.packages: The packages (generally JBoss Modules modules) that this layer provision in addition of implict extension module.

featurePacks.name: WildFly: Galleon Pack
featurePacks.description: Parent for various Galleon feature pack modules

modelReference.description: The root node of the server-level management model.

launch-type.description: The manner in which the server process was launched. Either "DOMAIN" for a domain mode server launched by a Host Controller, "STANDALONE" for a standalone server launched from the command line, or "EMBEDDED" for a standalone server launched as an embedded part of an application running in the same virtual machine.

management-major-version.description: The major version of the WildFly Core kernel management interface that is provided by this server.

management-micro-version.description: The micro version of the WildFly Core kernel management interface that is provided by this server.

management-minor-version.description: The minor version of the WildFly Core kernel management interface that is provided by this server.

name.description: The name of this server. If not set, defaults to the runtime value of InetAddress.getLocalHost().getHostName().

namespaces.description: Map of namespaces used in the configuration XML document, where keys are namespace prefixes and values are schema URIs.

organization.description: Identification of the current organization running this server.

process-type.description: The type of process represented by this root resource. Always has a value of "Server" for a server resource.

product-name.description: The name of the WildFly Core based product that is being run by this server.

product-version.description: The version of the WildFly Core based product release that is being run by this server.

profile-name.description: The name of the server's configuration profile.

release-codename.description: The codename of the WildFly Core release this server is running.

release-version.description: The version of the WildFly Core release this server is running.

running-mode.description: The current running mode of the server. Either NORMAL (normal operations) or ADMIN_ONLY.  An ADMIN_ONLY server will start any configured management interfaces and accept management requests, but will not start services used for handling end user requests.

runtime-configuration-state.description: The current persistent configuration state, one of starting, ok, reload-required, restart-required, stopping or stopped.

schema-locations.description: Map of locations of XML schemas used in the configuration XML document, where keys are schema URIs and values are locations where the schema can be found.

server-state.description: The current state of the server controller; either STARTING, RUNNING, RESTART_REQUIRED, RELOAD_REQUIRED or STOPPING.

suspend-state.description: The suspend state of the server

uuid.description: Unique Id of this server instance.

subsystem.description: The subsystems that make up the server's profile.

batch-delay.description: The interval, in milliseconds, between two consecutive exports. Default is 5000.

endpoint.description: The URL for the exporter endpoint.

export-timeout.description: The maximum allowed time, in milliseconds, to export data.

exporter-type.description: The name of the exporter to use

max-export-batch-size.description: The maximum number of traces to be exported in a given batch.

max-queue-size.description: The maximum number of traces in the queue before they are exported.

ratio.description: The ratio amount to use for the ratio sampler

service-name.description: Service name reported to the trace collector

span-processor-type.description: The type of processor to use. Valid values are 'simple' and 'batch'.

microprofile-lra-coordinator.description: The MicroProfile LRA Coordinator subsystem implemented by Narayana

host.description: Name of the Undertow subsystem 'host' resource that the LRA coordinator will be deployed to.

server.description: Name of the Undertow subsystem 'server' resource that the LRA coordinator will be deployed to.

microprofile-config-smallrye.description: WildFly Extension for MicroProfile Config With SmallRye

config-source-provider.description: Config Source Provider can be used to register new implementation for multiple Config Sources.

*.description: Config Source Provider can be used to register new implementation for multiple Config Sources.

class.description: Class of the ConfigSourceProvider to load

name.description: Name of the class of the config source to load

module.description: Module of the config source provider to load

config-source.description: ConfigSource provides a source for configuration values.

*.description: ConfigSource provides a source for configuration values.

class.description: Class of the config source to load

name.description: Name of the class of the config source to load

module.description: Module of the config source to load

dir.description: Directory that is scanned to config properties for this config source (file names are key, file content are value)

path.description: The path of the directory to scan. It is treated as an absolute path, unless the 'relative-to' attribute is specified, in which case the value is treated as relative to that path. If treated as an absolute path, the actual runtime pathname specified by the value of this attribute will be determined as follows: If this value is already absolute, then the value is directly used.  Otherwise the runtime pathname is resolved in a system-dependent way.  On UNIX systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current user directory. On Microsoft Windows systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current directory of the drive named by the pathname, if any; if not, it is resolved against the current user directory.

relative-to.description: The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute. The standard paths provided by the system include: jboss.home - the root directory of the JBoss AS distribution, user.home - user's home directory, user.dir - user's current working directory, java.home - java installation directory, jboss.server.base.dir - root directory for an individual server instance, jboss.server.data.dir - directory the server will use for persistent data file storage, jboss.server.log.dir - directory the server will use for log file storage, jboss.server.tmp.dir - directory the server will use for temporary file storage, and jboss.domain.servers.dir - directory under which a host controller will create the working area for individual server instances.

root.description: Whether the resolved directory is taken to be a root directory where the top level directories under the directory will each result in a directory type Config Source

ordinal.description: Ordinal value for the config source

properties.description: Properties configured for this config source and stored directly in WildFly management model.

endpoint.description: The URL to which metrics will be published.

exposed-subsystems.description: The names of the WildFly subsystems that exposes their metrics (or '*' to expose any subsystem metrics).

step.description: The step size (reporting frequency) to use in seconds.

prometheus.description: The Micrometer registry that makes metrics available in a Prometheus format

context.description: The context root from which to serve Prometheus metrics (e.g., "/metrics" or "/prometheus"). Note: Prometheus is not supported on host controllers.

security-enabled.description: Whether the context should be secured

otlp.description: The Micrometer registry that pushes observability signals to an external OTLP-compatible server

endpoint.description: The URL to which metrics will be published.

step.description: The step size (reporting frequency) to use in seconds.

mvc-krazo.description: Jakarta MVC implementation based on Eclipse Krazo

microprofile-reactive-streams-operators-.description: The Microprofile Reactive Streams Operators subsystem implemented by SmallRye

microprofile-opentracing-smallrye.description: WildFly Extension for MicroProfile OpenTracing With SmallRye.

default-tracer.description: Default tracer for the deployments if none is defined.

*.description: Tracer configuration.

propagation.description: List of formats to use for propagating the trace context.

reporter-flush-interval.description: The flush interval when reporting spans remotely.

reporter-log-spans.description: Whether the reporter should log the spans.

reporter-max-queue-size.description: The maximum queue size for use when reporting spans remotely.

sampler-param.description: The Jaeger sampler parameter. For a 'Constant' sampler 0 means no trace and 1 means all traces. For a 'probabilistic' sample this is the probability of sampling. For a 'Rate Limiting' sampler this define the number of traces per second.

sampler-type.description: The Jaeger sampler type. There are 4 supported type: 'const', 'probabilistic', 'ratelimiting' and 'remote'.

sender-auth-password.description: The Basic Auth password to be added on Authorization headers for requests sent to the endpoint.

sender-auth-token.description: The Auth Token to be added as "Bearer" on Authorization headers for requests sent to the endpoint.

sender-auth-user.description: The Basic Auth username to be added on Authorization headers for requests sent to the endpoint.

sender-binding.description: The outbound binding used to connect to the agent.

sender-endpoint.description: The full URL to the traces endpoint, like https://jaeger-collector:14268/api/traces

tracer_id_128bit.description: Opt-in to use 128 bit traceIds. By default, uses 64 bits.

microprofile-jwt-smallrye.description: WildFly Extension for MicroProfile JWT With SmallRye

microprofile-health-smallrye.description: WildFly Extension for MicroProfile Health With SmallRye

empty-liveness-checks-status.description: Defines the global status returned by the Health checks endpoints if no liveness probes have been defined in deployments.

empty-readiness-checks-status.description: Defines the global status returned by the Health checks endpoints if no readiness probes have been defined in deployments.

empty-startup-checks-status.description: Defines the global status returned by the Health checks endpoints if no startup probes have been defined in deployments.

security-enabled.description: True if authentication is required to access the HTTP endpoints on the HTTP management interface.

provider.description: Configuration for an OpenID Connect provider. If you have multiple deployments secured by the same OpenID provider you can share the provider configuration here.

*.description: Configuration for an OpenID Connect provider. If you have multiple deployments secured by the same OpenID provider you can share the provider configuration here.

allow-any-hostname.description: If set to 'true', hostname verification is skipped when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This can be useful in testing environments. This should never be set to 'true' in production environments as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

always-refresh-token.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem refreshes the token every time your application receives a web request, and a new request is sent to the OpenID provider to obtain a new access token. This can result in a higher load on the OpenID provider and may impact the performance of the application.

auth-server-url.description: The base URL of the Keycloak authorization server. This is Keycloak-specific. It is recommended to use the 'provider-url' instead.

authentication-request-format.description: The format to use for specifying query parameters in authentication request.

autodetect-bearer-only.description: Whether to auto-detect SOAP or REST clients based on headers like 'X-Requested-With', 'SOAPAction' or 'Accept'. If set to 'true', the subsystem sends an HTTP 401 status code to unauthenticated SOAP or REST clients instead of redirecting them to the OpenID provider login page. Set the value to 'true' if your application serves both applications and web services.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

client-keystore.description: The path to the client keystore to use when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This is optional.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

confidential-port.description: The confidential port used by the OpenID provider when communicating securely over SSL/TLS.

connection-pool-size.description: The connection pool size to use when communicating with the OpenID provider.

connection-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for establishing a connection with the remote host in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

connection-ttl-millis.description: The amount of time in milliseconds for the connection to be kept alive. A value less than or equal to zero is interpreted as an infinite value.

cors-allowed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-allowed-methods.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-exposed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Expose-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-max-age.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Max-Age' header. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

disable-trust-manager.description: Whether or not to make use of a trust manager when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This is optional. This should be set to 'true' only during development and never in production as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

enable-cors.description: Enable the Keycloak Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support. This is optional. This is Keycloak-specific.

expose-token.description: If set to 'true', an authenticated browser client can obtain the signed access token (through a Javascript HTTP invocation) via the URL 'root/k_query_bearer_token'. This is optional.

ignore-oauth-query-parameter.description: Disable query parameter parsing for the 'access_token'. Users will not be able to authenticate if they only pass in an 'access_token'.

principal-attribute.description: Indicates which value from the ID token to use as the principal for the identity. The principal defaults to the value of the 'sub' if the token attribute is null.

proxy-url.description: The URL for the HTTP proxy if one is used.

realm-public-key.description: The public key of the OpenID provider in PEM format. This is optional. It is not recommended to set it. If the public key is not set, the subsystem downloads the public key from the OpenID provider when needed. If the public key is set, the subsystem never downloads new keys from the OpenID provider, breaking the subsystem when the OpenID provider rotates its keys.

register-node-at-startup.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem sends a registration request to the OpenID provider. This attribute is useful only when your application is clustered.

register-node-period.description: If 'register-node-at-startup' is set to 'true', this specifies the frequency (in seconds) at which the node should be re-registered.

request-object-encryption-alg-value.description: The encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-encryption-enc-value.description: The content encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-signing-algorithm.description: The algorithm used to sign the request object. The default value fot this attribute is "none".

request-object-signing-key-alias.description: The key alias when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-key-password.description: The key password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-file.description: The path to the keystore to use when signing a request object. This is required if an asymmetric signing algorithm for request object is indicated.

request-object-signing-keystore-password.description: The keystore password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-type.description: The keystore type used to specify the client key pair used to sign request objects.

socket-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for the socket waiting for data after establishing the connection in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

ssl-required.description: Whether the communication with the OpenID provider should be over HTTPS. Valid values are: 'all' - to always require HTTPS, 'external' - to only require HTTPS for external requests, 'none' - if HTTPS is not required. This should be set to 'all' in production environments.

token-signature-algorithm.description: The token signature algorithm used by the OpenID provider.

token-store.description: Defines whether to store account information in an HTTP session or in a cookie.

truststore.description: The path to the truststore to use when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. Prefix the path with 'classpath:' to obtain the truststore from the deployment's classpath.

verify-token-audience.description: If set to 'true', then during bearer-only authentication, the subsystem verifies if the token contains the client name defined as an audience. It is recommended to set the value to 'true' for improved security.

secure-server.description: Configuration used to secure the management console using Keycloak.

*.description: Configuration used to secure the management console using Keycloak.

adapter-state-cookie-path.description: If set, this defines the path used in cookies set by the subsystem. This is useful when deploying an application in the root context path.

allow-any-hostname.description: If set to 'true', hostname verification is skipped when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This can be useful in testing environments. This should never be set to 'true' in production environments as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

always-refresh-token.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem refreshes the token every time your application receives a web request, and a new request is sent to the OpenID provider to obtain a new access token. This can result in a higher load on the OpenID provider and may impact the performance of the application.

auth-server-url.description: The base URL of the Keycloak authorization server. This is Keycloak-specific. It is recommended to use 'provider-url' instead.

authentication-request-format.description: The format to use for specifying query parameters in authentication request.

autodetect-bearer-only.description: Whether to auto-detect SOAP or REST clients based on headers like 'X-Requested-With', 'SOAPAction' or 'Accept'. If set to 'true', the subsystem sends an HTTP 401 status code to unauthenticated SOAP or REST clients instead of redirecting them to the OpenID provider login page. Set the value to 'true' if your application serves both applications and web services.

bearer-only.description: Enable Bearer-Token only authentication. Set this to 'true' if your application serves only web services and does not authenticate users.

client-id.description: The unique identifier for a client application registered in the OpenID provider.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

client-keystore.description: The path to the client keystore to use when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This is optional.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

confidential-port.description: The confidential port used by the OpenID provider when communicating securely over SSL/TLS.

connection-pool-size.description: The connection pool size to use when communicating with the OpenID provider.

connection-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for establishing a connection with the remote host in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

connection-ttl-millis.description: The amount of time in milliseconds for the connection to be kept alive. A value less than or equal to zero is interpreted as an infinite value.

cors-allowed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-allowed-methods.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-exposed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Expose-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-max-age.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Max-Age' header. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

credential.description: The credential used to communicate with the OpenID Connect provider.

secret.description: The client secret that was registered with the OpenID provider.

client-keystore-file.description: The path to the client keystore when the credential provider is used. This is optional.

client-keystore-type.description: The client keystore type when the credential provider is used.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore when the credential provider is used. This is required if 'client-keystore-file' has been specified.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key when the credential provider is used. This is required if 'client-keystore-file' has been specified.

token-timeout.description: The amount of time after which the token expires and can no longer be used to authenticate requests.

client-key-alias.description: The client key alias when the credential provider is used.

algorithm.description: The credential signature algorithm used by the OpenID provider.

disable-trust-manager.description: Whether or not to make use of a trust manager when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This is optional. This should be set to 'true' only during development and never in production as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

enable-basic-auth.description: Enable Basic authentication. This is not supported in the current release.

enable-cors.description: Enable the Keycloak Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support. This is optional. This is Keycloak-specific.

expose-token.description: If set to 'true', an authenticated browser client can obtain the signed access token (through a Javascript HTTP invocation) via the URL 'root/k_query_bearer_token'. This is optional.

ignore-oauth-query-parameter.description: Disable query parameter parsing for the 'access_token'. Users will not be able to authenticate if they only pass in an 'access_token'.

min-time-between-jwks-requests.description: If the subsystem recognizes a token signed by an unknown public key, it will try to download a new public key from the server. The subsystem won't try to download a public key if it already tried last in less than 'min-time-between-jwks-requests' seconds.

principal-attribute.description: Indicates which value from the ID token to use as the principal for the identity. The principal defaults to the value of the 'sub' if the token attribute is null.

provider.description: The OpenID Connect provider to use for authentication.

proxy-url.description: The URL for the HTTP proxy if one is used.

public-client.description: If set to 'true', no client credentials are sent when communicating with the OpenID provider.

public-key-cache-ttl.description: The maximum interval between two requests to retrieve new public keys in seconds. New public keys are downloaded when the subsystem recognizes a token signed by an unknown public key. Even if the token's key is already known, new public keys are downloaded periodically as per the interval set here at least once.

realm.description: The Keycloak realm to use for authentication.

realm-public-key.description: The public key of the OpenID provider in PEM format. This is optional. It is not recommended to set it. If the public key is not set, the subsystem downloads the public key from the OpenID provider when needed. If the public key is set, the subsystem never downloads new keys from the OpenID provider, breaking the subsystem when the OpenID provider rotates its keys.

redirect-rewrite-rule.description: The rewrite rule for the redirect URI. The rewrite rule is an object notation, where the key is a regular expression with which the redirect URI is matched and the value is the replacement String.

replacement.description: The replacement String in the rewrite rule for the redirect URI.

register-node-at-startup.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem sends a registration request to the OpenID provider. This attribute is useful only when your application is clustered.

register-node-period.description: If 'register-node-at-startup' is set to 'true', this specifies the frequency (in seconds) at which the node should be re-registered.

request-object-encryption-alg-value.description: The encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-encryption-enc-value.description: The content encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-signing-algorithm.description: The algorithm used to sign the request object. The default value fot this attribute is "none".

request-object-signing-key-alias.description: The key alias when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-key-password.description: The key password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-file.description: The path to the keystore to use when signing a request object. This is required if an asymmetric signing algorithm for request object is indicated.

request-object-signing-keystore-password.description: The keystore password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-type.description: The keystore type used to specify the client key pair used to sign request objects.

resource.description: The unique, legacy identifier for a client application registered in the OpenID provider. It is recommended to use the 'client-id'.

scope.description: A space separated list of scope values that should be used in the OIDC authentication request. Scopes can be used to request that specific sets of information be made available as Claim Values.

socket-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for the socket waiting for data after establishing the connection in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

ssl-required.description: Whether the communication with the OpenID provider should be over HTTPS. Valid values are: 'all' - to always require HTTPS, 'external' - to only require HTTPS for external requests, 'none' - if HTTPS is not required. This should be set to 'all' in production environments.

token-minimum-time-to-live.description: The subsystem will refresh the token if it will expire within the duration specified in 'token-minimum-time-to-live' seconds. This value should never exceed the access token lifespan. If the value is set to 0 seconds, the subsystem will refresh the token only if the token has expired.

token-signature-algorithm.description: The token signature algorithm used by the OpenID provider.

token-store.description: Defines whether to store account information in an HTTP session or in a cookie.

truststore.description: The path to the truststore to use when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. Prefix the path with 'classpath:' to obtain the truststore from the deployment's classpath.

turn-off-change-session-id-on-login.description: The Session ID is changed by default on a successful login. Set this to 'true' if you want to turn this off.

use-resource-role-mappings.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem will look inside the token for application-level role mappings for a user. If set to 'false', the subsystem will look at the realm-level for user-role mappings. This is optional.

verify-token-audience.description: If set to 'true', then during bearer-only authentication, the subsystem verifies if the token contains the client name defined as an audience. It is recommended to set the value to 'true' for improved security.

redirect-rewrite-rule.description: The rewrite rule for the redirect URI. The rewrite rule is an object notation, where the key is a regular expression with which the redirect URI is matched and the value is the replacement String.

*.description: The rewrite rule for the redirect URI. The rewrite rule is an object notation, where the key is a regular expression with which the redirect URI is matched and the value is the replacement String.

replacement.description: The replacement String in the rewrite rule for the redirect URI.

bearer-only.description: Enable Bearer-Token only authentication. Set this to 'true' if your application serves only web services and does not authenticate users.

client-id.description: The unique identifier for a client application registered in the OpenID provider.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

client-keystore.description: The path to the client keystore to use when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This is optional.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

confidential-port.description: The confidential port used by the OpenID provider when communicating securely over SSL/TLS.

connection-pool-size.description: The connection pool size to use when communicating with the OpenID provider.

connection-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for establishing a connection with the remote host in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

connection-ttl-millis.description: The amount of time in milliseconds for the connection to be kept alive. A value less than or equal to zero is interpreted as an infinite value.

cors-allowed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-allowed-methods.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-exposed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Expose-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-max-age.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Max-Age' header. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

credential.description: The credential used to communicate with the OpenID Connect provider.

secret.description: The client secret that was registered with the OpenID provider.

client-keystore-file.description: The path to the client keystore when the credential provider is used. This is optional.

client-keystore-type.description: The client keystore type when the credential provider is used.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore when the credential provider is used. This is required if 'client-keystore-file' has been specified.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key when the credential provider is used. This is required if 'client-keystore-file' has been specified.

token-timeout.description: The amount of time after which the token expires and can no longer be used to authenticate requests.

client-key-alias.description: The client key alias when the credential provider is used.

algorithm.description: The credential signature algorithm used by the OpenID provider.

disable-trust-manager.description: Whether or not to make use of a trust manager when communicating with the OpenID provider over HTTPS. This is optional. This should be set to 'true' only during development and never in production as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

enable-basic-auth.description: Enable Basic authentication. This is not supported in the current release.

enable-cors.description: Enable the Keycloak Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support. This is optional. This is Keycloak-specific.

expose-token.description: If set to 'true', an authenticated browser client can obtain the signed access token (through a Javascript HTTP invocation) via the URL 'root/k_query_bearer_token'. This is optional.

ignore-oauth-query-parameter.description: Disable query parameter parsing for the 'access_token'. Users will not be able to authenticate if they only pass in an 'access_token'.

min-time-between-jwks-requests.description: If the subsystem recognizes a token signed by an unknown public key, it will try to download a new public key from the server. The subsystem won't try to download a public key if it already tried last in less than 'min-time-between-jwks-requests' seconds.

principal-attribute.description: Indicates which value from the ID token to use as the principal for the identity. The principal defaults to the value of the 'sub' if the token attribute is null.

provider.description: The OpenID Connect provider to use for authentication.

proxy-url.description: The URL for the HTTP proxy if one is used.

public-client.description: If set to 'true', no client credentials are sent when communicating with the OpenID provider.

public-key-cache-ttl.description: The maximum interval between two requests to retrieve new public keys in seconds. New public keys are downloaded when the subsystem recognizes a token signed by an unknown public key. Even if the token's key is already known, new public keys are downloaded periodically as per the interval set here at least once.

realm.description: The Keycloak realm to use for authentication.

realm-public-key.description: The public key of the OpenID provider in PEM format. This is optional. It is not recommended to set it. If the public key is not set, the subsystem downloads the public key from the OpenID provider when needed. If the public key is set, the subsystem never downloads new keys from the OpenID provider, breaking the subsystem when the OpenID provider rotates its keys.

redirect-rewrite-rule.description: The rewrite rule for the redirect URI. The rewrite rule is an object notation, where the key is a regular expression with which the redirect URI is matched and the value is the replacement String.

replacement.description: The replacement String in the rewrite rule for the redirect URI.

register-node-at-startup.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem sends a registration request to the OpenID provider. This attribute is useful only when your application is clustered.

register-node-period.description: If 'register-node-at-startup' is set to 'true', this specifies the frequency (in seconds) at which the node should be re-registered.

request-object-encryption-alg-value.description: The encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-encryption-enc-value.description: The content encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-signing-algorithm.description: The algorithm used to sign the request object. The default value fot this attribute is "none".

request-object-signing-key-alias.description: The key alias when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-key-password.description: The key password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-file.description: The path to the keystore to use when signing a request object. This is required if an asymmetric signing algorithm for request object is indicated.

request-object-signing-keystore-password.description: The keystore password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-type.description: The keystore type used to specify the client key pair used to sign request objects.

resource.description: The unique, legacy identifier for a client application registered in the OpenID provider. It is recommended to use the 'client-id'.

scope.description: A space separated list of scope values that should be used in the OIDC authentication request. Scopes can be used to request that specific sets of information be made available as Claim Values.

socket-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for the socket waiting for data after establishing the connection in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

ssl-required.description: Whether the communication with the OpenID provider should be over HTTPS. Valid values are: 'all' - to always require HTTPS, 'external' - to only require HTTPS for external requests, 'none' - if HTTPS is not required. This should be set to 'all' in production environments.

token-minimum-time-to-live.description: The subsystem will refresh the token if it will expire within the duration specified in 'token-minimum-time-to-live' seconds. This value should never exceed the access token lifespan. If the value is set to 0 seconds, the subsystem will refresh the token only if the token has expired.

token-signature-algorithm.description: The token signature algorithm used by the OpenID provider.

token-store.description: Defines whether to store account information in an HTTP session or in a cookie.

truststore.description: The path to the truststore to use when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. Prefix the path with 'classpath:' to obtain the truststore from the deployment's classpath.

turn-off-change-session-id-on-login.description: The Session ID is changed by default on a successful login. Set this to 'true' if you want to turn this off.

use-resource-role-mappings.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem will look inside the token for application-level role mappings for a user. If set to 'false', the subsystem will look at the realm-level for user-role mappings. This is optional.

verify-token-audience.description: If set to 'true', then during bearer-only authentication, the subsystem verifies if the token contains the client name defined as an audience. It is recommended to set the value to 'true' for improved security.

redirect-rewrite-rule.description: The rewrite rule for the redirect URI. The rewrite rule is an object notation, where the key is a regular expression with which the redirect URI is matched and the value is the replacement String.

*.description: The rewrite rule for the redirect URI. The rewrite rule is an object notation, where the key is a regular expression with which the redirect URI is matched and the value is the replacement String.

replacement.description: The replacement String in the rewrite rule for the redirect URI.

credential.description: The credential used to communicate with the OpenID Connect provider.

algorithm.description: The credential signature algorithm used by the OpenID provider.

client-key-alias.description: The client key alias when the credential provider is used.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key when the credential provider is used. This is required if 'client-keystore-file' has been specified.

client-keystore-file.description: The path to the client keystore when the credential provider is used. This is optional.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore when the credential provider is used. This is required if 'client-keystore-file' has been specified.

client-keystore-type.description: The client keystore type when the credential provider is used.

secret.description: The client secret that was registered with the OpenID provider.

token-timeout.description: The amount of time after which the token expires and can no longer be used to authenticate requests.

realm.description: Configuration for a Keycloak realm. If you have multiple deployments secured by the same realm you can share the realm configuration here.

*.description: Configuration for a Keycloak realm. If you have multiple deployments secured by the same realm you can share the realm configuration here.

allow-any-hostname.description: If set to 'true', hostname verification will be skipped when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. This can be useful in testing environments. This should never be set to 'true' in production environments as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

always-refresh-token.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem refreshes the token every time your application receives a web request, and a new request is sent to Keycloak to obtain a new access token. This can result in a higher load on the Keycloak and may impact the performance of the application.

auth-server-url.description: The base URL of the Keycloak authorization server. It is recommended to use the 'provider-url' instead.

authentication-request-format.description: The format to use for specifying query parameters in authentication request.

autodetect-bearer-only.description: Whether to auto-detect SOAP or REST clients based on headers like 'X-Requested-With', 'SOAPAction' or 'Accept'. If set to 'true', the subsystem sends an HTTP 401 status code to unauthenticated SOAP or REST clients instead of redirecting them to the Keycloak login page. Set the value to 'true' if your application serves both applications and web services.

client-key-password.description: The password for the client key. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

client-keystore.description: The path to the client keystore to use when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. This is optional.

client-keystore-password.description: The password for the client keystore. This is required if 'client-keystore' has been specified.

confidential-port.description: The confidential port used by Keycloak when communicating securely over SSL/TLS.

connection-pool-size.description: The connection pool size to use when communicating with Keycloak.

connection-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for establishing a connection with the remote host in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

connection-ttl-millis.description: The amount of time in milliseconds for the connection to be kept alive. A value less than or equal to zero is interpreted as an infinite value.

cors-allowed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-allowed-methods.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-exposed-headers.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Expose-Headers' header. This should be a comma-separated string. This is optional. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

cors-max-age.description: If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is enabled, this sets the value of the 'Access-Control-Max-Age' header. If not set, this header is not returned in CORS responses.

disable-trust-manager.description: Whether or not to make use of a trust manager when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. This is optional. This should be set to 'true' only during development and never in production as it disables verification of SSL certificates.

enable-cors.description: Enable the Keycloak Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) support. This is optional.

expose-token.description: If set to 'true', an authenticated browser client can obtain the signed access token (through a Javascript HTTP invocation) via the URL 'root/k_query_bearer_token'. This is optional.

ignore-oauth-query-parameter.description: Disable query parameter parsing for the 'access_token'. Users will not be able to authenticate if they only pass in an 'access_token'.

principal-attribute.description: Indicates which value from the ID token to use as the principal for the identity. The principal defaults to the value of the 'sub' if the token attribute is null.

proxy-url.description: The URL for the HTTP proxy if one is used.

realm-public-key.description: The public key of the Keycloak realm in PEM format. This is optional. It is not recommended to set it. If the public key is not set, the subsystem downloads the public key from Keycloak when needed. If the public key is set, the subsystem never downloads new keys from Keycloak, breaking the subsystem when Keycloak rotates its keys.

register-node-at-startup.description: If set to 'true', the subsystem sends a registration request to Keycloak. This attribute is useful only when your application is clustered.

register-node-period.description: If 'register-node-at-startup' is set to 'true', this specifies the frequency (in seconds) at which the node should be re-registered.

request-object-encryption-alg-value.description: The encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-encryption-enc-value.description: The content encryption algorithm used to encrypt the request object.

request-object-signing-algorithm.description: The algorithm used to sign the request object. The default value fot this attribute is "none".

request-object-signing-key-alias.description: The key alias when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-key-password.description: The key password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-file.description: The path to the keystore to use when signing a request object. This is required if an asymmetric signing algorithm for request object is indicated.

request-object-signing-keystore-password.description: The keystore password when a key pair is used to sign request objects.

request-object-signing-keystore-type.description: The keystore type used to specify the client key pair used to sign request objects.

socket-timeout-millis.description: The timeout for the socket waiting for data after establishing the connection in milliseconds. A timeout value of zero is interpreted as an infinite timeout, and a negative value is interpreted as undefined.

ssl-required.description: Whether the communication with Keycloak should be over HTTPS. Valid values are: 'all' - to always require HTTPS, 'external' - to only require HTTPS for external requests, 'none' - if HTTPS is not required. This should be set to 'all' in production environments.

token-signature-algorithm.description: The token signature algorithm used by Keycloak.

token-store.description: Defines whether to store account information in an HTTP session or in a cookie.

truststore.description: The path to the truststore to use when communicating with Keycloak over HTTPS. Prefix the path with 'classpath:' to obtain the truststore from the deployment's classpath.

verify-token-audience.description: If set to 'true', then during bearer-only authentication, the subsystem verifies if the token contains the client name defined as an audience. It is recommended to set to 'true' for improved security.

microprofile-lra-participant.description: The Microprofile LRA Participant subsystem implemented by Narayana

lra-coordinator-url.description: Configuration of the lra-coordinator-url, used by the LRA Participant subsystem.

exposed-subsystems.description: The names of the WildFly subsystems that exposes their metrics (or '*' to expose any subsystem metrics).

prefix.description: Prefix prepended to the name of the WildFly metrics exposed by the HTTP endpoints.

security-enabled.description: True if authentication is required to access the HTTP endpoint on the HTTP management interface.This attribute overrides the value specified in the security-enabled attribute of the /subsystem=metrics resource.

microprofile-reactive-messaging-smallrye.description: The Microprofile Reactive Messaging subsystem implemented by SmallRye

opentelemetry-tracing.description: Configures OpenTelemetry tracing for the connectors. If the resource is not present, that is the same as specifying 'never' for each connector

config.description: Configures OpenTelemetry tracing for the connectors. If the resource is not present, that is the same as specifying 'never' for each connector

amqp-connector.description: Configure OpenTelemetry tracing for the AMPQ connector

kafka-connector.description: Configure OpenTelemetry tracing for the Kafka connector

path.description: A list of named filesystem paths.

*.description: A named filesystem path.

name.description: The name of the path. Cannot be one of the standard fixed paths provided by the system: jboss.home - the root directory of the JBoss AS distribution; user.home - user's home directory; user.dir - user's current working directory; java.home - java installation directory; jboss.server.base.dir - root directory for an individual server instance. Note that the system provides other standard paths that can be overridden by declaring them in the configuration file. See the 'relative-to' attribute documentation for a complete list of standard paths.

path.description: The actual filesystem path. Treated as an absolute path, unless the 'relative-to' attribute is specified, in which case the value is treated as relative to that path. If treated as an absolute path, the actual runtime pathname specified by the value of this attribute will be determined as follows: If this value is already absolute, then the value is directly used.  Otherwise the runtime pathname is resolved in a system-dependent way.  On UNIX systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current user directory. On Microsoft Windows systems, a relative pathname is made absolute by resolving it against the current directory of the drive named by the pathname, if any; if not, it is resolved against the current user directory.

read-only.description: True if added by the system, false if configured by user. If true, the path cannot be removed or modified.

relative-to.description: The name of another previously named path, or of one of the standard paths provided by the system. If 'relative-to' is provided, the value of the 'path' attribute is treated as relative to the path specified by this attribute. The standard paths provided by the system include: jboss.home - the root directory of the JBoss AS distribution; user.home - user's home directory; user.dir - user's current working directory; java.home - java installation directory; jboss.server.base.dir - root directory for an individual server instance; jboss.server.data.dir - directory the server will use for persistent data file storage; jboss.server.log.dir - directory the server will use for log file storage; jboss.server.tmp.dir - directory the server will use for temporary file storage; jboss.domain.servers.dir - directory under which a host controller will create the working area for individual server instances.

stream.description: Provides the overlay content file a response attachment. The response result value is the unique id of the attachment.

platform-mbean.description: Provides the management interface for monitoring and management of the Java virtual machine as well as the operating system on which the Java virtual machine is running. Exposes the JDK-provided JMX MBeans in the java.lang and java.nio JMX domains.

type.description: The platform MBeans, organized by the value of the 'type' property in the MBean's ObjectName.

memory.description: The management interface for the memory system of the Java virtual machine.

heap-memory-usage.description: The current memory usage of the heap that is used for object allocation.

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

non-heap-memory-usage.description: The current memory usage of non-heap memory that is used by the Java virtual machine.

init.description: The amount of memory in bytes that the Java virtual machine initially requests from the operating system for memory management.

used.description: The amount of used memory in bytes.

committed.description: The amount of memory in bytes that is committed for the Java virtual machine to use.

max.description: The maximum amount of memory in bytes that can be used for memory management.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

object-pending-finalization-count.description: The approximate number of objects for which finalization is pending.

verbose.description: Whether verbose output for the memory system is enabled.

operating-system.description: The management interface for the operating system on which the Java virtual machine is running.

arch.description: The operating system architecture. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "os.arch", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

available-processors.description: The number of processors available to the Java virtual machine.

name.description: The operating system name. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "os.name", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

system-load-average.description: The system load average for the last minute. The load average may not be available on some platforms; if the load average is not available, a negative value is returned.

version.description: The operating system version. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "os.version", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

compilation.description: The management interface for the compilation system of the Java virtual machine

compilation-time-monitoring-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports the monitoring of compilation time.

name.description: The name of the Just-in-time (JIT) compiler.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

total-compilation-time.description: The approximate accumulated elapsed time (in milliseconds) spent in compilation. A Java virtual machine implementation may not support compilation time monitoring. If "compilation-time-monitoring-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

buffer-pool.description: The management interface for a buffer pool, for example a pool of direct or mapped buffers.

name.description: The name representing this buffer pool.
The name representing this buffer pool.

*.description: The management interface for a buffer pool, for example a pool of direct or mapped buffers.

count.description: An estimate of the number of buffers in the pool.

memory-used.description: An estimate of the memory that the Java virtual machine is using for this buffer pool in bytes, or -1 if an estimate of the memory usage is not available.

name.description: The name representing this buffer pool.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

total-capacity.description: An estimate of the total capacity of the buffers in this pool. A buffer's capacity is the number of elements it contains and the value of this attribute is an estimate of the total capacity of buffers in the pool in bytes.

class-loading.description: The management interface for the class loading system of the Java virtual machine.

loaded-class-count.description: The number of classes that are currently loaded in the Java virtual machine.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

total-loaded-class-count.description: The total number of classes that have been loaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

unloaded-class-count.description: The total number of classes unloaded since the Java virtual machine has started execution.

verbose.description: Whether the verbose output for the class loading system is enabled.

runtime.description: The management interface for the runtime system of the Java virtual machine.

boot-class-path.description: The boot class path that is used by the bootstrap class loader to search for class files. If attribute "boot-class-path-supported" is "false" or if a security manager is installed and the caller does not have ManagementPermission("monitor"), then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

boot-class-path-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports the boot class path mechanism used by the bootstrap class loader to search for class files.

class-path.description: The Java class path that is used by the system class loader to search for class files. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.class.path", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

input-arguments.description: The input arguments passed to the Java virtual machine which does not include the arguments to the main method. If a security manager is installed and the caller does not have ManagementPermission("monitor"), then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

library-path.description: The Java library path. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.library.path", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

management-spec-version.description: The version of the specification for the management interface implemented by the running Java virtual machine.

name.description: The name representing the running Java virtual machine.

object-name.description: String representation the object name of this platform managed object.

spec-name.description: The Java virtual machine specification name. uptime.description: The uptime of the Java virtual machine in milliseconds.

vm-name.description: The Java virtual machine implementation name. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.name", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.vendor", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

vm-version.description: The Java virtual machine implementation version. If a security manager is installed and it does not allow access to system property "java.vm.version", then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

threading.description: The management interface for the thread system of the Java virtual machine.

all-thread-ids.description: All live thread IDs. If a security manager is installed and the caller does not have ManagementPermission("monitor"), then a "read-attribute" operation reading this attribute will fail, and the value for this attribute in the result for the "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

current-thread-cpu-time.description: The total CPU time for the current thread in nanoseconds, or -1 if "thread-cpu-time-enabled" is "false". A Java virtual machine implementation may not support CPU time measurement. If "thread-cpu-time-supported", is "false" trying to read this attribute via the "read-attribute" operation will result in failure, and the value of this attribute in the result of a "read-resource" operation will be "undefined".

current-thread-cpu-time-supported.description: Whether the Java virtual machine supports CPU time measurement for the current thread.

current-thread-user-time.description: The CPU time that the current thread has executed in user mode in nanoseconds, or -1 if "thread-cpu-time-enabled" is "false". A Java virtual machine implementation may not support CPU time measurement. *.description: Interface definition

any.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be that the IP address meets at least one of a nested set of criteria, but not necessarily all of the nested criteria. The value of the attribute is a set of criteria. An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

inet-address.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not the address matches the given value. Value is either an IP address in IPv6 or IPv4 dotted decimal notation, or a hostname that can be resolved to an IP address. An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

link-local-address.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not the address is link-local. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

loopback.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not it is a loopback address.  An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

loopback-address.description: Attribute indicating that the IP address for this interface should be the given value, if a loopback interface exists on the machine. A 'loopback address' may not actually be configured on the machine's loopback interface. Differs from inet-address in that the given value will be used even if no NIC can be found that has the IP specified address associated with it. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

multicast.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not its network interface supports multicast.  An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

nic.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether its network interface has the given name. The name of a network interface (e.g. eth0, eth1, lo). An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

nic-match.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether its network interface has a name that matches the given regular expression. Value is a regular expression against which the names of the network interfaces available on the machine can be matched to find an acceptable interface. An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

point-to-point.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not its network interface is a point-to-point interface. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection

public-address.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not it is a publicly routable address. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection

site-local-address.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or it is a site-local address. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection

subnet-match.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or it the address fits in the given subnet definition. Value is a network IP address and the number of bits in the address' network prefix, written in "slash notation"; e.g. "192.168.0.0/16". An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

up.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether its network interface is currently up. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection

virtual.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether its network interface is a virtual interface. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection

any-address.description: Attribute indicating that sockets using this interface should be bound to a wildcard address. The IPv6 wildcard address (::) will be used unless the java.net.preferIpV4Stack system property is set to true, in which case the IPv4 wildcard address (0.0.0.0) will be used. If a socket is bound to an IPv6 anylocal address on a dual-stack machine, it can accept both IPv6 and IPv4 traffic; if it is bound to an IPv4 (IPv4-mapped) anylocal address, it can only accept IPv4 traffic.

inet-address.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not the address matches the given value. Value is either an IP address in IPv6 or IPv4 dotted decimal notation, or a hostname that can be resolved to an IP address. An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

link-local-address.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not the address is link-local. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

loopback.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not it is a loopback address.  An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

loopback-address.description: Attribute indicating that the IP address for this interface should be the given value, if a loopback interface exists on the machine. A 'loopback address' may not actually be configured on the machine's loopback interface. Differs from inet-address in that the given value will be used even if no NIC can be found that has the IP specified address associated with it. An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

multicast.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether or not its network interface supports multicast.  An 'undefined' or 'false' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

name.description: The name of the interface.

nic.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether its network interface has the given name. The name of a network interface (e.g. eth0, eth1, lo). An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

nic-match.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be whether its network interface has a name that matches the given regular expression. An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.

not.description: Attribute indicating that part of the selection criteria for choosing an IP address for this interface should be that the IP address *does not* meet any of a nested set of criteria. The value of the attribute is a set of criteria (e.g. 'loopback') whose normal meaning is reversed. An 'undefined' value means this attribute is not relevant to the IP address selection.
